reviews.review_msg: Michael was a great prof with a flipped class style where most content was taught asynchronously allowing for typical lectures to be used for help on the current week's assignments. Very group project heavy, with a different group every week, but was good for learning the many different analysis tools in the course.

Mylanta. Probably the most organized and accessible professor I've had in my undergraduate degree. Sure there's a steep learning curve with all the material at the start, but once you're in the groove this class is really fun and interesting! If you love group projects, this class is good for you. His lower score is old reviews only Cheers!

Michael is the best professor I have had in my four years at SFU. Not only is he very good at explaining why the material matters in the real world, he knows every student by name and is very flexible for the labs if you have something that comes up. Heavily recommend and I'm sad I will never have a professor like Michael again.

Great prof, confused as to why he has so many negative reviews. I am taking BUS462 with him this semester (summer2018). He is very good at explaining the bigger picture, but it is expected that you learn how to do things on your own. There are group assignments every week, which you must come prepared for if you want to do well in this course.
One of the best profs at Beedie. Very experienced and knowledgeable, you will learn a ton. Get a good group.
He looks good but his class is another story. Just an average class, non-directive after all.

Teaches and explains things like they are a piece of cake, then drills down and asks the most complex and confusing questions.  An example: an MC question 3 sentences long, 2 of the sentences are complicated and irrelevant to the question being asked.  Just meant to confuse you and take up your time (time pressured quizes and assignment).

ok first off, I think he looks like Will Ferrell and I love it. Brydon is pretty pro in his field, the problem is he is not very good at getting the point across to students. He's off in his own world and doesn't really half the stuff he teaches isn't really useful for us. However, he is really nice and willing to change deadlines, etc, sometimes.
getting an 'A' without knowing anything any bit in the class. Exams are easier than previous exams.

One of the worst profs in my 5 year BBA. Nightmare for my last business course. Power assignment too confusing no one understand anything. Not helpful to explain. class ends at 8:30 but students have to go his office hour after 9:30 when the lab closed. Classes are boring. Difficult to keep attention. Every assignment takes greater than 5 to 20 hrs

He seems to be a very disorganized when it comes to teaching material and lecture preparation. The course is difficult, and most of the time you have to figure things out by yourself (a bit of technical knowledge will actually helps). He's somewhat helpful in the lab, but still, this is a challenging course for 3 hours a week.
Good prof. He is very strict with the curve, so be sharp and try and try and do extra well on individual work. He is helpful. I've taken 2 courses with him now, and would take more.

He actullay has a good sense of humor. Nice prof, very intense course (lots of work) and high expectations. you have to compete against some of the smartest and most technically savvy students of business faculty. Mike is very helpful and class is very interesting.

Taught R for the majority of the class despite low application irl other than specialized roles, but knowledgable about specific details in analytics. Came off as egoistic during presentations, asking analytics related q's but not taught in class. Picked on a student publicly for contribution which wasn't a good look. Doesn't know about git

Medhi did a great job at teaching for the first time. Although it was a regurgitation of 336, he was good at explaining the concepts and demonstrating tableau. I hope for future students he introduces programs such as R. He's a good man and very helpful.
I love this guy. Really really nice prof, and even though it's hard to express appreciation to him during online lectures, I hope he sees this and knows he's doing a great job.

Several issues with this prof and I don't recommend his class. His marking is unfair and he provides no feedback on assignments, and no opportunity to improve. He stopped teaching after week 5, and my team and I had to Google everything. He moved all assignments to be due within the last few weeks of classes. Too busy with outside work, don't take

Decided to delay all our assignments to the end of the semester, now swamped with work. When Covid-19 became an issue, he promised to be available and have increased accessibility. All lies, he completely abandoned us. He cancelled lectures before Covid even became an issue, we haven't been taught for ALMOST 6 WEEKS. Never take this man's classes

His class is very disorganized as he keeps delaying assignments until the end of the semester. His lecture is never clear and he usually just scribble stuff on the whiteboard. We havent even had any lecture for a month so we have to google all the code by ourselves for assignments.

A complete waste of my time. Nate googles all lecture content as he teaches during class. That is, IF he decides to teach. Google search was the real prof of BUS462. Pushes back all 5 assignments till end of the term. Blames COVID-19 for not being available for questions, but what about the weeks before school was cancelled? HM. Not convinced.
Lectures were extremely disorganized, felt like he was making the syllabus as he taught. constantly moved from topic to topic. Assignments were vague and so were his answers to any questions I asked.

We haven't had lectures for a long time. We're asked to do 5 regression/classification models he's never taught. Basically, students are browsing Wikipedia for a list of random models to meet the required '5 models'. Kaggle is more organized than this. Code Academy is better than this. What the heck is this? This is a self-taught class.

He is the worst professor I have ever had, I can't even believe him. He has not done lectures for a month at this point and does not help students answer any questions. We are expected to self learn and completed 3/4 of the term assignments. We didn't even learn stuff on the midterm. He doesn't even reply back to emails asking for clarification.

Worst prof Ive ever had in the history of my undergrad. Makes false promises to be available for questions, but does not follow through. He was not available during normal class times for the last 3 weeks during quarantine. Too busy sending us pictures of his ski trips throughout the term to actually care about teaching his classes.

Nate's lectures are disorganized and confusing. He speaks way too fast and frequently jumps from topic to topic during class. Simple concepts are lost in his long rants about data and technology. There are no slides or textbook in this class and his notes are useless as they are just random and vague concepts scribbled on the board.
Amin is a very nice guy and he wants you to succeed. You get to learn a lot of useful material throughout the term. Prepare for power assignments in advance and do some practice exams before final.

Wouldn't say it's easy, the course is designed to be technical, but this Prof is super nice with help if you ask for it. Not only he's helpful, but he understands the pains of students and keeps on trying to find ways to alleviate them. The prof has a cmpt and data background, so don't expect your usual business prof.

Very nice and an easy marker. Final is very fair and he always tries to help students as much as possible. Interesting to see things from his computer science background point of view as well as business.

Although he is new but Amin is very knowledgeable to the subject. You will find the course is heavy on weekly power assignments and quizzes but Amin will try to answer your questions and his gradings are pretty easy.

Prof. Amin has a deep understanding of business analytics and he is always open to industry-related questions. Understanding that most of the students in this class do not have a computing science background, he set a reasonable expectation and introduced us to additional tools and methods . 10/10 would take this course with him again.
Great prof. Always listens to his students and gives good feedback on student work. If you don't fully understand course content, ask him and he will give you an excellent explanation.
If you pre-read/listen to the given course materials before class, lecture attendance isn't necessary. He Amin is very knowledgeable and helpful in tutorials. Lectures require more spice.

Go to class - Landon isn't the clearest or most thrilling of professors, but without his words, his slides will not be so intuitive. As there are no tutorials, but merely labs, going to class if the only obligation you have as a student. He will try his best to make the course interesting, and the exam follows what he said would be included.

Nice guy but you won't learn anything from him. You don't get feedback until the after the semester so it's impossible to know how you're doing. If you want to get your money's worth and actually learn something, take it with a different prof.

You can tell he is dedicated to teaching and treats his job seriously. But BUS 462 requires a lot of stats knowledge from 336. The assignments require a lot of effort. On average it took my group 10 to 18 hours for each one. The good thing is that he is open to questions and suggestions, so go for help and ask him to give you practice finals.

Landon is a friendly and intelligent new professor. As far as teaching goes, you can tell he tries and has yet to find his full stride, but he is still better than most business professors. BUS462 is not at all difficult, although some might struggle if they have little experience with exploratory open-ended assignments, and basic math / stats.

Ridiculously difficult and tight deadlines. Difficult weekly WebCT quizzes. Expects you to remember and apply everything from BUS336. Assignments are more difficult and take more effort than usual projects. Lectures are very boring. Lecture notes don't make sense on their own so cannot fully use to study for final, leaving me nothing to study from.

So the prof might be monotone and not as fun as you imagine, but the class is well constructed, get ready to work hard get high marks. The class is challenging and teaches you technical analytic tools and skills and you will have a final project at the end to apply what you learn. If you get an A you can ask her for reference letter!

The final is easy and all you need to study is the lecture slides. However, the labs are bad since she tries to introduce way too much coding material and does little explaining. You will cover Python, R, and Knime in this course and still come out feeling like you learned almost nothing about coding. A good group is crucial for the group project.
Very helpful and accessible. The course is interesting and teaches you some practical skills. Perhaps most importantly, she listens to students for feedback and will make adjustments.
solid prof, adjusted course to feedback when necessary. will explain and help you when needed.
